abstract: Venture capital investors warn of common trend in which extra protections included in late-stage financing terms of start-ups are leading to overvaluation of so-called unicorns, or start-up tech companies valued at over $1 billion; terms, which are meant to protect founders and later-stage investors, and are controversial among early-stage investors, and while they should dilute value they are not often disclosed.
lead_paragraph: Terms providing insurance against subsequent developments appeal to company founders because they provide new cash at the highest nominal valuation, reducing dilution if all goes well.

headline.main: Protections for Late Investors Can Inflate Start-Up Valuations

snippet: Terms providing insurance against subsequent developments appeal to company founders because they provide new cash at the highest nominal valuation, reducing dilution if all goes well.
